page.title: Timeline of the feminist art movement in New Zealand

revision.comment: duplicate categorization; already in subcat
revision.text:
This is a timeline of the [[feminist art movement]] in [[New Zealand]] (or Aotearoa/New Zealand as it is often known in inclusive circles). It lists important figures, collectives, publications, exhibitions and moments that have contributed to discussion and development of the movement. For the indigenous [[Māori people|Māori]] population, the emergence of the [[feminist art movement]] broadly coincided with the emergence of [[Māori Renaissance]].
==1970s==
'''1972'''
The feminist publication [[Broadsheet (magazine)|''Broadsheet'']] is co-founded by Anne Else and [[Sandra Coney]] in [[Auckland]]. It is New Zealand's first feminist magazine, and provides regular arts coverage. It ceases publication in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Else|first1=Anne|title=Gender inequalities - Areas of discrimination|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/28622/broadsheet|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=15 November 2012}}</ref>
'''1974'''
Feminist poet [[Heather McPherson]] starts The Women Artists Group in Christchurch and begins working towards establishing the women's art journal ''Spiral,'' and the Spiral Collective.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/spiral-collectives/in-the-beginning-there-was-heather-d2ebbf4dd63c|title=In the beginning there was Heather.|last=Evans|first=Marian|date=31 May 2016|website=Spiral Collective|access-date=}}</ref>
'''1975'''
The [[Robert McDougall Art Gallery]] in Christchurch (now the [[Christchurch Art Gallery]]) organises ''Women's Art: An Exhibition of Six Women Artists'' to mark International Women's Year. The exhibition is curated by artist [[Allie Eagle]], then Exhibitions Officer at the gallery.<ref>{{cite book|title=Women's Art: An Exhibition of Six Women Artists|date=1975|publisher=Robert McDougall Art Gallery|location=Christchurch|url=http://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/media/uploads/2010_08/WomansArt1975.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
Works from photographer [[Fiona Clark (photographer)|Fiona Clark]]'s series 'Dance Party', taken at a gay lib dance party at Auckland University in 1974, are withdrawn from the touring photography exhibition ''[[The Active Eye]]'' after accusations of indecency.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wells|first1=Peter|title=Incandescent Moment: Fiona Clark's Go Girl|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 2003|issue=106|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issue106/Clark.htm}}</ref>
'''1976'''
The women's art journal ''Spiral'' begins publication.<ref name="Cook">{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Megan|title=Women’s movement - Arts and spirituality|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/womens-movement/page-9|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=13 July 2012}}</ref> The ''International Women's Film Festival'' tours Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington and Auckland.
'''1977'''
Members of Women's artists groups, including [[Heather McPherson]] and [[Allie Eagle]], work together to produce the Women's Art Environment at the Canterbury Society of Arts.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1977|title=The exhibitions : United Women's Convention 3–8 June|url=http://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/media/uploads/2010_08/1977-05-73.pdf|journal=CSA News|doi=|pmid=|access-date=17 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Else|first1=Anne|title=Gender inequalities - Arts and culture|url=http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/photograph/28656/womens-art-environment-1977|website=Te Ara: The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=McPherson|first=Heather|last2=Eagle|first2=Allie|last3=Keir|first3=Anna|last4=Paul|first4=Joanna|last5=Johnson|first5=Rosemary|year=1978|title=The Women's Environment at the '77 Women's Convention|url=|journal=Spiral (Christchurch, N.Z.)|issue= 3|pages=24–40|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
'''1978'''
[[Allie Eagle]] show the works ''This woman died I care'' (based on a banned photograph of a woman who died after having an illegal abortion) and ''Empathy for a Rape Trial Victim''; the exhibition stokes controversy and the artist receives hate mail.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zusters|first1=Jane|title=Allie Eagle: Artist|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Summer 1994–1995|issue=73|pages=53–57}}</ref>
'''1979'''
The Wellington Women's Gallery opens.<ref name ='Cook'/> Founded by Marian Evans, Anna Keir and Bridie Lonie the gallery was established as a non-profit, designed to 'support and promote women artists’.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Marian|title=They Might Have Completely Forgotten Us|url=https://medium.com/spiral-collectives/they-might-have-completely-forgotten-us-26b55cd68e69#.qdmzqosww|website=Spiral Collectives|accessdate=10 April 2016|date=9 February 2016}}</ref>
The National Art Gallery (now the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]]) establishes the Women's Art Archives, designed to collect the 'existing, neglected work by women and keep track of new work'. The archive is expanded to include Australian and Pacific women artists.<ref name ='Cook'/>
==1980s==
'''1980'''
The National Art Gallery stages the exhibition ''Women in Communication,'' curated by exhibitions officer Louise Upton. It includes an open forum to support prints and photographs from New Zealand women artists. Work by [[Robin White (artist)|Robin White]], [[Vivian Lynn]], Kate Coolahan and Gillian Chaplin were shown. The exhibition toured to [[Palmerston North]] and [[Whangarei]] and included video tapes from the Los Angeles Women's Video Centre.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Welsh|first=Robyn|date=1 September 1980|title=A gentle triumph for feminist art...but this faintly discriminatory National Gallery show may never be repeated|url=|journal=New Zealand Woman's Weekly}}</ref>
'''1981'''
The [[Wellington Women's Gallery]] stages the exhibition ''Mothers'', which tours New Zealand throughout 1981-1982.<ref name="Cull">{{cite journal|last1=Cull|first1=Chloe|title=Themes in Māori Women’s Art: How the Body ‘Speaks’ Within the Work of Māori Women Artists of the Seventies and Eighties|journal=Oculus|date=2014|url=http://static1.squarespace.com/static/53bb2870e4b0dfc914b2b65a/t/5494bf88e4b050c0df015455/1419034504754/Oculus2014Web_Cull.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''1982'''
The [[F1 Sculpture Project]] is staged in a large disused factory building on Tory Street in Wellington. A significant number of female artists make temporary installation pieces and a range of events were staged, including a two-day Women Sculptors Seminar.<ref>{{cite web|title=Factory 1 (F1) Sculpture Project 1982|url=http://thecommunityarchive.org.nz/node/65922/description|website=The Community Archive|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Strathdee|first1=Barbara|title=Women Artists at the F1 New Zealand Sculpture Project|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 1983|issue=26}}</ref>
[[Vivian Lynn]] shows her major sculptural work [http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/object/840813 ''Guarden gates''], now in the collection of the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kirker|first1=Anne|title=Vivian Lynn's Garden Gates|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 1983|issue=26|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issues21to30/lynn.htm|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Vivian Lynn talks about her work Guarden gates, 1982|url=http://blog.tepapa.govt.nz/2010/10/29/vivian-lynn-talks-about-her-work-guarden-gates-1982/|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=31 December 2014|date=29 October 2010}}</ref>
The Feminist Art Network group is established in Auckland, advocating for an increased profile for work by women and feminist work.<ref>{{cite web|title=Feminist Art Network Archive|url=http://www.aucklandartgallery.com/explore-art-and-ideas/archives/19595|website=Auckland Art Gallery|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
'''1983'''
The national art magazine ''Art New Zealand'' dedicates its Autumn issue to female artists and the women's art movement. Art historian [[Cheryll Sotheran]] writes an overview of the current state and reception of women's art in New Zealand, noting that 'most critics in New Zealand avoid or condemn exhibitions of women's art which use gender difference as a political weapon. The women whose art receives favourable reviews (or in many cases any reviews at all) are those whose work fits the modernist mould, are not feminists, are asexual and apolitical.'<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sotheran|first1=Cheryll|title=Replacing Women in Art History|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issues21to30/replacing.htm|website=Art New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=Autumn 1983}}</ref>
Haeata, the Māori women’s art collective, is established in Wellington. Members include [[Keri Kaa]], [[Patricia Grace]], [[Robyn Kahukiwa]] and [[Irihapeti Ramsden]]. It supports a number of significant female Māori artists and produces and tours exhibitions.<ref name ='Cull'/>
[[Bronwynne Cornish]] is commissioned by the [[Auckland Art Gallery]] to produce a solo work and creates a multi-part ceramic installation titled ''Dedicated to the Kindness of Mothers''.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Eastmond | first1=Elizabeth | title=Bronwynne Cornish's 'Dedicated to the kindness of mothers' | journal=Art New Zealand | date=Autumn 1984 | issue=30|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issues21to30/cornish.htm}}</ref> In April, [[Gretchen Albrecht]] selects work for a group exhibition arranged by the Outreach Gallery in Auckland, ''New Works By Women''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rosier|first1=Pat|title=New Works By Women, 1983|journal=Broadsheet|date=June 1983|issue=110|pages=42}}</ref>
In June, Juliet Batten facilitates ''The Menstrual Maze'' at Greer's Factory in Auckland.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nicholson|first1=Bronwen|title=The Menstrual Maze|journal=Broadsheet|date=September 1983|issue=112|pages=46}}</ref> The June issue of feminist magazine ''Broadsheet'' includes a special feature on feminist artists. It includes Batten's article 'What is a feminist artist?'.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Batten|first1=Juliet|title=What is a feminist artist?|journal=Broadsheet|date=June 1983|issue=110}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Broadsheet 110, June 1983: 'Special feature on feminist art'|url=http://best-of-3.blogspot.co.nz/2016/03/broadsheet-110-june-1983-special.html|website=Best of 3|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
1983 also sees the founding of [[Aotearoa Moananui a Kiwa Weavers]], a government funding stream specific to female-dominated art forms, Māori and Pacific weaving. It is now known as [[Te Roopu Raranga Whatu o Aotearoa]] and Māori-only.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maoriart.org.nz/weavers-c-52_75.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304153600/http://www.maoriart.org.nz/weavers-c-52_75.html |archivedate=2012-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
'''1984'''
[[Robyn Kahukiwa]] exhibits her series of paintings ''Wahine toa: women of Māori myth''; the paintings are also reproduced in a book with text by [[Patricia Grace]].<ref name='Mane-Wheoki'/>
'''1985'''
Artist Juliet Batten leads the 'One Hundred Women' event at [[Te Henga (Bethells Beach)]] as part of the ANZART project.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barton|first1=Christina|title=Post-object and conceptual art - What is post-object art|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/43823/one-hundred-women|website=Te Ara - The online encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref>
'''1986'''
The journal ''Antic'' is launched. Art historian [[Tina Barton]] describes it as 'one forum for a more analytical explication of feminist theory and its applications in the field of literature, criticism and the visual arts, which could be seen as an alternative to the ''Broadsheet'' or ''Art New Zealand'' models.' It ceases publication in 1990.<ref name ='Barton 1993'>{{cite journal|last1=Barton|first1=Christina|title=Ten Years On: Reviewing the terrain for women in art in New Zealand|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Spring 1993|issue=68|pages=50–52}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Antic 1986 - 1990: full list of contents|url=http://best-of-3.blogspot.co.nz/2016/03/antic-1986-1990-full-list-of-contents.html|website=Best of 3|accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref>
Art critic Lita Barrie delivers a paper, 'Remissions: toward a deconstruction of phallic unequivocality: deferrals', at the Critic's Conference at the National Art Gallery. Informed by contemporary French theory and calling for a 'critical feminist art practice', Barrie attacked the essentialist form of feminist art practice common at the time, sending 'shock waves through the community of women artists to whom her paper was addressed'.<ref name = 'Barton 1993'/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Rice|first1=Rebecca|last2=Williams|first2=Mark|title=Criticism and the arts - Issues of identity, 1960s onwards|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/criticism-and-the-arts/page-4|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
The first edition of Anne Kirker's ''New Zealand women artists'' is published by Reed Methuen.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kirker|first1=Anne|title=New Zealand women artists|date=1986|publisher=Reed Methuen|location=Auckland|isbn=0474001814}}</ref>
Elizabeth Eastmond and Merimeri Penfold's ''Women and the Arts in New Zealand: Forty Works 1936–1986'' is published by Penguin Books.<ref name ='Eastmond and Penfold>{{cite book|last1=Penfold|first1=Merimeri|last2=Eastmond|first2=Elizabeth|title=Women and the Arts in New Zealand: Forty Works 1936–1986|date=1986|publisher=Auckland|location=Penguin Books|isbn=014009234X}}</ref>
The Haeata collective organises the exhibition ''Karanga Karanga'', which shows in Auckland, Wellington and Gisborne.<ref name ='Cull'/>
[[Vivian Lynn]] shows ''Gates of the Goddess – a southern crossing attended by the Goddess'' at the [[Govett-Brewster Art Gallery]]; the work is now in the collection of the [[Auckland Art Gallery]]).<ref name='Eastmond and Penfold'/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Megan|title='Women's movement – Arts and spirituality'|url=http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/artwork/27927/goddess-gates|website=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=22 February 2016|date=16 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Women and the arts in New Zealand – Forty Works: 1936–86|last = Eastmond|first = Elizabeth|publisher = Penguin Books|year = 1986|isbn = 014009234X|location = Auckland|pages = |last2 = Penfold|first2 = Merimeri}}</ref>
'''1988'''
The National Art Gallery organises an exhibition of the work of American artist [[Barbara Kruger]], curated by [[Jenny Harper]]. The exhibition is held at the Gallery's satellite contemporary art space, Shed 11. Kruger visits New Zealand for the opening of the exhibition and delivers a public lecture.<ref name="Clifford">{{cite web|last1=Clifford|first1=Jess|title=Looking out, looking in|url=http://arts.tepapa.govt.nz/off-the-wall/7693/looking-in-looking-out|website=Off The Wall|publisher=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Untitled (We are unsuitable for framing)|url=http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/object/36996|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
Marian Evans, Bridie Lonie and Tilly Lloyd co-edit ''A Women's picture book : 25 women artists of Aotearoa New Zealand''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Evans|first1=Marian|last2=Lonie|first2=Bridie|last3=Lloyd|first3=Tilly|title=A Women's picture book : 25 women artists of Aotearoa New Zealand|date=1988|publisher=GP Books|location=Wellington|isbn=0477013953}}</ref> The authors intend to include a number of Māori artists, including [[Irihapeti Ramsden]], [[Jacqueline Fraser]] and [[Robyn Kahukiwa]] but several withdraw after concerns about material included in the book which they felt to breach [[Tapu (Polynesian culture)|tapu]].<ref name="Mane-Wheoki">{{cite web|last1=Mane-Wheoki|first1=Jonathan|title=Contemporary Māori art – ngā toi hōu - New developments in contemporary art|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/contemporary-maori-art-nga-toi-hou/page-3|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=14 November 2014}}</ref>
[[Shona Rapira Davies]] and [[Robyn Kahukiwa]] collaborate on the exhibition ''Whakamaemae'' ('To feel pain') at [[City Gallery Wellington]]; the exhibition includes Rapira Davies' major sculptural work ''Nga Morehu''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nga Morehu|url=http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/object/43005|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''1989'''
Following on from the exhibition of Kruger's work, National Art Gallery director [[Luit Bieringa]] curates an exhibition of work by photographer [[Cindy Sherman]], also staged at Shed 11.<ref name="Clifford"/>
==1990s==
'''1990'''
This year marks New Zealand's sesquicentennial. A number of Māori women artists withdraw from the National Art Gallery's exhibition ''Kohia ko Taikaka Anake'' after learning that senior female artists will be made subordinate to senior male artists in its presentation.<ref name="Mane-Wheoki"/> The Haeata collective presents ''Hineteiwaiwa'', the ‘womanhouse’, for the ''Mana Tiriti'' exhibition at [[City Gallery Wellington]].<ref name="Mane-Wheoki"/>
'''1992'''
[[Cheryll Sotheran]] is appointed as the founding CEO of the new [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]], which merges New Zealand's national museum and national art gallery.
'''1993'''
This year marks the 100th anniversary of [[women's suffrage in New Zealand]].
''Art New Zealand'' dedicates its Spring issue that year to female artists and feminist topics. Art historian Tina Barton is commissioned to write a review of the decade since the last issue of the magazine devoted to women artists.<ref name ='Barton 1993'/> A number of exhibitions exploring women in New Zealand's art history and feminist art issues are staged around the country, including ''[[Alter / Image]]'' in Wellington and Auckland, ''Mediatrix : new works by seven women artists'' at Artspace in Auckland (curated by Priscilla Pitts and featuring Mary-Louise Browne, Denise Kum, [[Julia Morison]], Marie Shannon, Deborah Smith, Aromea Tahiwi and [[Barbara Tuck]]); ''Unruly Practices'' (a series of solo projects by feminist artists living in Auckland - [[Carole Shepheard]], [[Claudia Pond Eyley]], Mary McIntyre, [[Christine Hellyar]] and [[Sylvia Siddell]]) at [[Auckland Art Gallery]], ''White Camellias : a century of women's artmaking in Canterbury'' and ''Women on women : art in Dunedin since 1893'' at the [[Dunedin Public Art Gallery]], curated by Linda Tyler.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mediatrix : new work by seven women artists : an exhibition to mark the centenary of women's suffrage in New Zealand|url=http://natlib.govt.nz/records/22161487|website=National Library of New Zealand|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=White Camellias: A Century of Art Making by Canterbury Women|url=http://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/exhibitions/white-camellias|website=Christchurch Art Gallery|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Women on women : art in Dunedin since 1893|url=http://natlib.govt.nz/records/22206191|website=National Library of New Zealand|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref> ''Alter / Image'' was also one of four inaugural exhibitions, all featuring female artists, that marked the opening of [[City Gallery Wellington]] in its new location in the old Public Library building in Wellington's Civic Square; the others were ''[[Rosemarie Trockel]]'', ''Te Whare Puanga'' (recent weaving and tivaevae by Maori and Pacific Island women in Wellington) and ''He Tohu: The New Zealand Room'', a site-specific project by [[Jacqueline Fraser]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Exhibition advertisement|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Spring 1993|issue=68|page=unpaginated}}</ref> An updated version of Anne Kirker's 1986 book ''New Zealand Women Artists'' is published as ''New Zealand women artists : a survey of 150 years'' by Reed Methuen.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kirker|first1=Anne|title=New Zealand women artists : a survey of 150 years|date=1993|publisher=Auckland|location=Reed Methuen|isbn=9768097302}}</ref>
'''1994'''
Australian art magazine ''Artlink'' devotes its Autumn issue to 'Art & the Feminist Project'. The issue features articles by New Zealand writers [[Tina Barton]] ('Making (a) difference: Suffrage year celebrations and the visual arts in New Zealand') and Anne Kirker ('Re-orienting feminism in Aotearoa').<ref>{{cite web|title=Art & the Feminist Project|url=https://www.artlink.com.au/issues/1410/art-26-the-feminist-project/|website=Artlink|accessdate=26 February 2016}}</ref>
==2000s–present==
'''2000'''
The [[Govett-Brewster Art Gallery]] stages ''In glorious dreams'', an exhibition of new work by women artists.<ref>{{cite web|title=In glorious dreams|url=http://nlnzcat.natlib.govt.nz/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=610512|website=National Library of New Zealand catalogue|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2001'''
Artist [[Jacqueline Fraser]] is selected, along with Peter Robinson, to represent New Zealand in its first participation at the [[Venice Biennale]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mane-Wheoki|first1=Jonathan|title=Contemporary Māori art – ngā toi hōu - Contemporary Māori art in the 2000s|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/contemporary-maori-art-nga-toi-hou/page-5|website=Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref>
'''2002'''
The Govett-Brewster Art Gallery stages ''Go Girl'', a survey of the work of photographer Fiona Clark. The exhibition includes works withdrawn from the 1975 exhibition ''The Active Eye'' after accusations of indecency relating to their depiction of the LGBT community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Go Girl at New Plymouth’s Govett-Brewster Gallery|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0209/S00079/go-girl-at-new-plymouths-govett-brewster-gallery.htm|website=Scoop.co.nz|accessdate=23 February 2016|date=25 September 2002}}</ref>
'''2004'''
The Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa stages ''Judy Darragh: So ... You Made It'', the only solo exhibition of a contemporary New Zealand artist presented at the museum between its opening in 1998 and the 'Toi Art' refreshment that opened in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Judy Darragh: So ... you made it?|url=http://www.tepapa.govt.nz/WhatsOn/exhibitions/Pages/JudyDarragh.aspx|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tonagrewa|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2008'''
The Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa presents the exhibition ''We are unsuitable for framing''. Curated by Charlotte Huddleston, the exhibition is titled after a work by Barbara Kruger held in the museum's collection and included in the artist's 1988 exhibition in Wellington. It includes works produced between 1974 and 2005 and aimed to explore 'aspects of identity, gender, sexuality, and mythology'.<ref>{{cite web|title=We are unsuitable for framing|url=http://www.tepapa.govt.nz/WhatsOn/exhibitions/Pages/WeAreUnsuitableForFraming.aspx|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2009'''
The [[Adam Art Gallery]] holds a workshop titled 'Out Loud: Using the ‘F’ Word Today', featuring a range of female curators and artists, to accompany its survey exhibition of the work of [[Vivian Lynn]], '' I, HERE, NOW Vivian Lynn''.<ref>{{cite web|title=February-March 2009|url=http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/calendar/february-march/|website=Adam Art Gallery|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2012'''
[[The Dowse Art Museum]] stages the touring exhibition ''In Spite of Ourselves: Approaching Documentary'', which includes a work by Qatari/US artist, Sophia Al-Maria, ''For Your Eyes Only'' (2007) which shows female members of a family preparing for a wedding in a space in a house only used by women and children. The artists requests that the video work only be shown to female visitors: when the museum complies with this request protests are made that men are being excluded from the museum.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Spite of Ourselves: Approaching Documentary|url=http://dowse.org.nz/exhibitions/detail/in-spite-of-ourselves-approaching-documentary|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=In Spite of Everything|url=http://dowse.org.nz/news/blog/2012/in-spite-of-everything|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2013'''
Writer Thomasin Sleigh publishes an analysis of the contemporary editorial approach of ''Art New Zealand'', concluding that 'the artist most likely for Art New Zealand to run an article on would be a Pakeha painter, and his work would most likely be written about by a Pakeha man employed by an academic institution.'<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sleigh|first1=Thomasin|title=The Stuttering Conversation: Art New Zealand in 2013|url=http://lumiere.net.nz/index.php/art-new-zealand-in-2013/|website=The Lumiere Reader|accessdate=22 February 2016|date=21 February 2013}}</ref>
'''2014'''
Art History honours students at the University of Auckland organise ''Voicing the Visible'', an exhibition of female and feminist artists work from the university's collection for the Gus Fisher Gallery.<ref>{{cite web|title=Voicing the Visible|url=http://www.ingenio-magazine.com/voicing-the-visible/|website=Ingenio|publisher=University of Auckland Alumni organisation|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
'''2015'''
[[Enjoy Public Art Gallery]] in Wellington presents ''Enjoy Feminisms'', an exhibition programme that sought to demonstrate the multiple meanings of feminism to contemporary artists, and publishes ''Love Feminisms'', an online journal to accompany the exhibition programme.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enjoy Feminisms|url=http://www.enjoy.org.nz/node/3665|website=Enjoy Public Art Gallery|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Love Feminisms|url=http://journal.enjoy.org.nz/love-feminisms/editorial|website=Enjoy Public Art Gallery|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
The [[Adam Art Gallery]] presents ''Fragments of a World: Artists Working in Film and Photography 1973–1987'', curated by Dr Sandy Callister, an exhibition investigating 'the intersection of feminism, new technologies, and a disruptive epoch'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fragments of a World|url=http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/past-exhibitions/10053/|website=Adam Art Gallery|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
[[The Dowse Art Museum]] in Lower Hutt organises an 'Art + Feminism' Wikipedia edit-a-thon to improve coverage of New Zealand women artists.<ref>{{cite web|title=Art + Feminism edit-a-thon|url=http://dowse.org.nz/events/art-feminism-wikipedia-edit-a-thon|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2016'''
The Dowse Art Museum organises 'Four Waves of Feminism', a symposium exploring current and historical feminist art, activity and research.<ref>{{cite web|title=Four Waves of Feminism|url=http://dowse.org.nz/events/four-waves-of-feminism|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref>
Barbara Brookes' ''A History of New Zealand Women'' is published by [[Bridget Williams Books]]. Heavily illustrated with the work of women artists including [[Olivia Spencer Bower]], [[Rita Angus]], [[Margaret Stoddart]] and [[Louise Henderson]], the reproductions are presented 'not simply as illustrations for the immediate text but as a narrative in themselves. ... this is, presenting a woman's perspective.'<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brookes|first1=Barbara|title=A history of New Zealand women|date=2016|publisher=Bridget Williams Books|location=Wellington|isbn=9780908321476|page=486}}</ref>
The Adam Art Gallery presents ''Bad Visual Systems'', an exhibition by Berlin-based, New Zealand-born artist Ruth Buchanan. For the exhibition Buchanan shows the work of German artists Judith Hopf and [[Marianne Wex]]. The exhibition presents panels from Wex's photographic book ''Let’s Take Back Our Space''; sheets from the book had been printed in a 1984 edition of the feminist magazine ''Broadsheet'' when Wex was living in Wellington.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bad Visual Systems|url=http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/current-exhibition/|website=Adam Art Gallery|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>
'''2018'''
2018 marks the 125th anniversary of women's suffrage in New Zealand.
Christchurch Art Gallery presents ''We Do This'', an exhibition of work by women artists. largely from the gallery's permanent collection, in a 'recharged contemporary hang to mark 125 years of women’s suffrage.'<ref>{{cite web |title=We Do This |url=https://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/exhibitions/we-do-this |website=Christchurch Art Gallery Te Puna o Waiwhetū |accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref>

[[File:Uppsala Conflict Data Program Office at Uppsala University, Sweden..JPG|thumb|The UCDP is located at [[Uppsala University|Uppsala University's]] Department of Peace and Conflict Research (at left) in Gamla Torget.]] The '''Uppsala Conflict Data Program''' ('''UCDP''') is a data collection project on organized [[violence]] housed at [[Uppsala University]] in [[Sweden]] that has been collecting information on [[armed conflict]] since 1946<ref name="pcr"/> and making it publicly available through its annual report, ''States in Armed Conflict.'' Beginning in Since 2004, the constantly-updated UCDP is also publicly available.<ref name="pcr" /> The UCDP collects both [[Quantitative research|quantitative]] and [[Qualitative research|qualitative data]] on organized violence (e.g., fatality statistics, [[Georeferencing|georeferenced]] event data, and armed actor and conflict descriptions) that is used by [[social science]] researchers, [[journalist]]s, and [[Politician|policymakers]].
==Background== The UCDP began recording information on ongoing violent conflicts in the 1970s.<ref name="pcr">{{cite web |author=Erik Melander |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/program_overview/ |title=UCDP Program Overview |accessdate=January 22, 2017 |publisher=[[Department of Peace and Conflict Research]], [[University of Upsala]] |date=nd |location=[[Uppsala]], [[Sweden]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206111450/http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/program_overview/ |archive-date=February 6, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> It became clear that more systematic and global data on armed conflicts was necessary for conducting research in the expanding academic discipline of [[peace and conflict studies]].
Initially, the program collected data only on so-called "armed conflicts", defined as fighting exceeding 25 battle-related deaths between two actors of which at least one was a [[State (polity)|state]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Box 256 |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/definitions/definition_of_armed_conflict/#i |title=UCDP definition of armed conflict |publisher=Pcr.uu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730162625/http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/definitions/definition_of_armed_conflict#i |archive-date=2013-07-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In later years, the data gathering grew, and the program also began collecting data on "non-state conflicts" (where neither party was a state) and "one-sided violence" (where an organized group attacked unarmed [[civilian]]s).
The UCDP's data is published annually in such publications as the ''[[Stockholm International Peace Research Institute|SIPRI Yearbook]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sipri.org/yearbook/2012 |title=and the |publisher=Sipri.org |date=2012-06-04 |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref> and the ''[[Journal of Peace Research]]''. The UCDP also makes its data publicly available through its website and previously in its publication, ''States in Armed Conflict''.
==Organization== The UCDP is located at the Department of Peace and Conflict Research of Uppsala University in Sweden. The program is led by Associate Professor Kristine Eck, and employs approximately 10-15 research assistants and researchers. A number of scholars and Ph.D. candidates are also attached to the program and tasked with carrying out research for the collection of conflict data. In addition to collecting data, the program disseminates knowledge on trends and dynamics of armed conflict to the public via lectures at academic and government forums.
===Cooperation=== The UCDP works closely with both the [[Peace Research Institute Oslo]] (PRIO) and the [[Human Security Report Project]], based within the School for International Studies at [[Simon Fraser University]] in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]]. The UCDP collaborates with PRIO to create its datasets and provides the Human Security Research Project with data for its annual publication, the ''[[Human Security Report 2005|Human Security Report]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsrgroup.org/human-security-reports/2012/overview.aspx |title=Overview - Human Security Report 2012 |publisher=Hsrgroup.org |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref> The UCDP's data is published annually in collaboration with the [[Stockholm International Peace Research Institute]] (SIPRI) and appears in the ''SIPRI Yearbook''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sipri.org/yearbook/2012 |title=SIPRI Yearbook 2012 — www.sipri.org |publisher=Sipri.org |date=2012-06-04 |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref>
==Research== Hundreds of scholars have used the UCDP's data for research.<ref>{{cite web |author=Box 256 |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/publications/Publications_using_UCDP_data/ |title=Publications using UCDP data - Uppsala universitet |publisher=Pcr.uu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617161647/http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/publications/Publications_using_UCDP_data |archive-date=2013-06-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The UCDP couples data collection with research on conflict resolution and the dynamics of conflicts.<ref name="pcr" /> Much of the research done by UCDP staff is published in the UCDP's ''States in Armed Conflict'' annual report, the annual ''SIPRI Yearbook'', and the ''Journal of Peace Research''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Box 256 |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/publications/ |title=Publications - Uppsala universitet |publisher=Pcr.uu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref>
==UCDP/PRIO Armed Conflict Database==
The Armed Conflict Dataset is a joint project between the UCDP and PRIO that records armed conflicts from 1946–2016 that result in a minimum of 25 battle-related deaths and in which at least one actor is the government of a state. Data is collected by keying specific search words in the [[Factiva|Factiva Database]], an online resource containing over 10,000 different newspapers, newswires, and other sources, as well as published books, case studies, and journals (''[[Africa Research Bulletin]]'', ''[[Africa Confidential]]'', [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] publications). The dataset is updated annually, with Version 17.1-2017 being the most recent.
Every armed conflict is classified as a dyad in the dataset and assigned an ID number. A dyad consists of two conflicting primary parties. Dyads can last multiple years and are coded for intensity level ("minor" for those with less than 1,000 deaths; "major" for those with more than 1,000 deaths), region ([[Americas]], [[Asia]], [[Middle East]], [[Africa]], [[Europe]]), incompatibility (government, territory, government and territory), and type (extrasystemic, interstate, internal, internationalized internal). The start date, end date, year, and location of conflict are also provided as well as the precision of the start and end date.
===Publications=== UCDP data has been published in the ''SIPRI Yearbook'' since 1988. Since 1993, a list of all armed conflicts also appears in the ''Journal of Peace Research''. Data on non-state conflicts appears in the ''Human Security Report'' from 2004. The UCDP has also releases (annually) its own report, ''States in Armed Conflict''. UCDP data is also frequently used by journalists, government agencies, and other organizations to produce overviews of peace and conflict in the world. One prominent index that uses UCDP data is the [[Global Peace Index]].<ref>[http://www.visionofhumanity.org/gpi/home.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704165325/http://www.visionofhumanity.org/gpi/home.php |date=July 4, 2008 }}</ref>
==UCDP Battle-Related Deaths Dataset== A battle-related death is one that is caused by combat between conflicting parties over a contested incompatibility. These deaths can be caused by traditional battlefield fighting, [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrilla activities]], [[urban warfare]], and any kind of [[bombardment]] of military units, cities, and villages. Guerrilla activities include [[Hit-and-run tactics|hit-and-run attacks]] and [[ambush]]es, and examples of urban warfare include [[bomb]]s, [[explosion]]s, and [[assassination]]s. Targets of attacks are generally military, state institutions, and state representatives. However, civilians are [[collateral damage]], and both military and [[Civilian casualties|civilian deaths]] are accounted for in the dataset.
UCDP has three ways of estimating battle-related deaths: best estimate, low estimate, and high estimate. The best estimate is the aggregate of the most reliable numbers for all battle-related incidents during a year. The low estimate is the aggregate of low estimates for all battle-related incidents during a year, and the high estimate is the aggregate of high estimates for all battle-related incidents during a year. These estimates are found in both conflict-year based datasets and dyad-year based datasets. The averages of deaths in the most recent of each kind of dataset are:
{| class="wikitable" |- | Conflict-year dataset || bdBest || bdLow || bdHigh |- | Average || 918 || 868 || 1,287 |- | Dyad-year dataset || bdBest || bdLow || bdHigh |- | Average || 705 || 666 || 979 |}
UCDP gathers and updates data on a yearly basis. They have datasets available from 1989 to 2016. Every event lists the date of the event, reporting source, primary source, actors involved, place of event, what happened, and the estimates of fatalities. The staff reads all the reports, and the information is entered manually. Furthermore, the aggregate results are compared to figures in official documents, special reports, and news media.
UCDP uses both printed and electronic public sources for gathering information. The main source is the Factiva Database that is composed of over 10,000 newspapers, newswires, and other sources from around the globe. UCDP uses at least one major newswire ([[Reuters]], [[Xinhua News Agency|Xinhua]], [[EFE]]) and [[BBC Monitoring]]. Additional sources include news agencies, newly published books, case studies, journals like ''Africa Research Bulletin'', research reports, documents of international and multinational organizations, publications by NGOs such as [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Amnesty International]], and documents of fighting parties. Sources are judged according to the context in which they are published, and reports are traced back to the primary source to establish reliability.
==UCDP's definitions of organized violence== The program divides armed conflict into three categories: "state-based conflict", "non-state conflict", and "one-sided violence".
'''State-based conflict''' refers to what most people intuitively perceive as "war"; fighting either between two states, or between a state and a rebel group that challenges it. The UCDP defines an armed state-based conflict as: "An armed conflict is a contested incompatibility that concerns government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in at least 25 battle-related deaths in one calendar year".<ref>{{cite web|author=Box 256 |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/definitions/#i |title=UCDP definition of armed conflict |publisher=Pcr.uu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref> The program's definition differs somewhat from other data collection programs, such as the [[Correlates of War]] Project, which only counts conflicts where at least 1,000 deaths have been recorded during one calendar year. In UCDP, data such an armed conflict is labelled as having the intensity level of "war", whilst armed conflicts that reap between 25 and 999 battle-related deaths are seen as having the intensity of a "minor" armed conflict.<ref>{{cite web|author=Box 256 |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/definitions/#i |title=Definition of intensity levels |publisher=Pcr.uu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref>
'''Non-state conflicts''' are those conflicts in which none of the warring parties is a state. Examples of non-state conflicts include the [[Fatah–Hamas conflict (2006–07)|Fatah–Hamas conflict of 2006 and 2007]], [[Ethnic conflict|inter-ethnic group conflicts]] such as the [[Lou Nuer]]–[[Murle people|Murle]] conflict of 2009–2012, and inter-[[Drug cartel|cartel]] violence in the [[Mexican Drug War]].
'''One-sided violence''' is defined as: "The use of armed force by the government of a state or by a formally organized group against civilians which results in at least 25 deaths in a year".<ref>{{cite web|author=Box 256 |url=http://www.pcr.uu.se/research/ucdp/definitions/#o |title=UCDP definition of one-sided violence |publisher=Pcr.uu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref> Examples include actions by the governments of [[Sudan]], [[Myanmar]], and [[Syria]] against civilians, as well as actions of non-state organizations such as [[Los Zetas]], Al-Qaeda, and the [[Lord's Resistance Army]] against civilians.
===List of state-based conflicts in 2011=== In 2011, the UCDP reported 37 active state-based armed conflicts:
'''Europe''' • Russia (territory: Caucasus Emirate)
'''Middle East''' • Iran (government) • Iraq (government) • Israel (territory: Palestine) • Syria (government) • Turkey (territory: Kurdistan) • Yemen (government)
'''Asia''' • Afghanistan (government) • Cambodia, Thailand (territory: common border) • India (territory: Kashmir) • India (government) • Myanmar (territory: Karen) • Myanmar (territory: Kachin) • Myanmar (territory: Shan) • Pakistan (territory: Baluchistan) • Pakistan (government) • Philippines (territory: Mindanao) • Philippines (government) • Tajikistan (government) • Thailand (territory: Patani)
'''Africa''' • Algeria (government) • Central African Republic (government) • Ethiopia (territory: Ogaden) • Ethiopia (territory: Oromiya) • Ivory Coast (government) • Libya (government) • Mauritania (government) • Nigeria (government) • Rwanda (government) • Senegal (territory: Casamance) • Somalia (government) • Southern Sudan (government) • Sudan (government) • Sudan (territory: Abyei) • Uganda (government)
'''Americas''' • Colombia (government) • USA (government)
Out of these 37 armed conflicts, a total of six ([[Al-Qaeda insurgency in Yemen|Yemen]], [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]], [[War in North-West Pakistan|Pakistan]], [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libya]], [[Somali Civil War|Somalia]] and [[Sudan internal conflict (2011–present)|Sudan]]) reached the intensity level of "War", meaning that more than 1,000 battle-related deaths were recorded in 2011.
In 2012, six conflicts also reached the intensity level of "war".

==Criticism== [[Edward S. Herman|Edward Herman]], Professor Emeritus of Finance at the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]], and his colleague David Peterson, who together co-authored ''The Politics of Genocide'', have accused the UCDP of using "politicized [...] methodologies" in an effort to "minimize U.S.- and Western-led warmaking and killing." Exemplifying these assertions, they compare the classification{{by whom|date=July 2013}} of US involvement in [[Guatemala]] and the perception of Soviet involvement in Afghanistan by the program.<ref>{{cite web|author=Edward S Herman and David Peterson |url=http://www.zcommunications.org/reality-denial-steven-pinkers-apologetics-for-western-imperial-volence-by-edward-s-herman-and-david-peterson |title=Reality Denial : Steven Pinker's Apologetics for Western-Imperial Volence; under the sub-heading "Sources and methods" |publisher=Zcommunications.org |date= |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref>
==UCDP on the internet== The UCDP's homepage is located at <span class="plainlinks">http://www.ucdp.uu.se</span>. The UCDP also has an on-line database of organised violence, accessible at <span class="plainlinks"> http://www.ucdp.uu.se/gpdatabase/search.php</span>. The database provides free information on state-based and non-state conflicts, as well as one-sided violence. It also includes descriptive information on causes and histories of conflicts and one-sided violence and brief descriptions of rebel groups, governments, and related items.
=== UCDP for iPhone and Android === As of July 2010, the UCDP Conflict Database is available as an [[iPhone]] application<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/se/app/uppsala-conflict-database/id380077089?mt=8 |title=Uppsala Conflict Database för iPhone, iPod touch och iPad i iTunes App Store |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=2012-11-19 |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref> and an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] application.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=se.uppsala.ucdp&feature=search_result&hl=en |title=Uppsala Conflict Database - Android Apps on Google Play |publisher=Play.google.com |date=2012-10-18 |accessdate=2013-06-30}}</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = What Should Legal Analysis Become? | image = Cover_image_of_What_Should_Legal_Analysis_Become.jpg | caption = | author = [[Roberto Mangabeira Unger]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | genre = [[Law]] | publisher = [[Verso Books]] | release_date = 1996 | pages = 198 | isbn = 1-85984-969-5 | congress= K290.U54 1996 | oclc= 34192097 | preceded_by = [[Politics: A Work In Constructive Social Theory]] | followed_by = [[Democracy Realized: The Progressive Alternative]] }}
'''''What Should Legal Analysis Become?''''' is a book by philosopher and politician [[Roberto Mangabeira Unger]]. First published in 1996, the book germinated from lectures Unger gave at Yale Law School, Columbia Law School, and the London School of Economics. In the book, Unger argues that in order to transform society to be more radically democratic, it is necessary to penetrate the specialized professions so that we can talk about, and imagine, institutions effectively. Unger focuses on the legal profession in this book, setting forth a vision of law as "institutional imagination." He presents a program for changing the nature of the legal profession so that less power is vested in legal professionals and institutions, and legal analysis is reoriented to be more egalitarian and advance more effectively the democratic project.
==Reception==
[[Jeremy Waldron]], reviewing ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?'' in the ''[[Columbia Law Review]]'',<ref>Jeremy Waldron, "Dirty Little Secret" (review of ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?''), 98 Columbia Law Review 510 (1998).</ref> praised the book as an "eminently readable" text encompassing many of the same themes that Unger explored in his three-volume ''Politics: A Work in Constructive Social Theory''. Waldron notes that Unger's argument in the book has a negative and a positive side. Waldron finds the negative side of Unger's argument—in which Unger attacks contemporary American legal analysis as "incapable of contributing to serious social reform" (as Waldron summarizes the argument)—"exciting," and states that Unger's negative argument "goes right to the heart of the difficulties about political agency that disfigure modern legal scholarship."<ref>Waldron 517</ref> Waldron finds the positive side of Unger's argument "somewhat less convincing." The positive argument, which contains Unger's exploration of the alternative futures of democracy, Waldron dismisses as "broad-brush sketching of some rather familiar social-democratic ideals .... [that] might have been produced by any intelligent person on the left."<ref>Waldron 512-513</ref> Waldron sums up his assessment by stating that "so far as the positive suggestions are concerned, one is left frustrated by this book. The negative account of mainstream legal analysis is provocative, and the critique of its orientation to the courts is important and timely."<ref>Waldron 528</ref>
Robin Bradley Kar contends that Unger's constructive program in ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?'' is inconsistent with his negative criticisms of contemporary American legal interpretation. In his review of the book in the ''[[Yale Law Journal]]'',<ref>"Legal Analysis and the Perversions of Theory (review of ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?''), 106 Yale Law Journal 2685 (1997)</ref> Kar argued that Unger's criticism of contemporary legal analysis rests on the idea that we should not rest our interpretations of law upon general "policies of collective welfare and principles of moral and political right,"<ref>Kar 2686</ref> because such reliance works to suppress important parts of the democratic compromises that help advance radical democratic aims. But, Kar points out, Unger's constructive, positive program rests on "similarly general conceptions of democracy and human nature."<ref>Kar 2690</ref> Kar concludes that "Unger's entire work thus provides us with a useful moral about the dangers inherent in interpreting the law through the lens of theory."<ref>Kar 2686</ref>
Lorne Sossin, reviewing the book in the ''University of Toronto Law Journal'',<ref>"The Politics of Imagination" (review of ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?'') 47 University of Toronto Law Journal 523 (1997)</ref> praised ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?'' as a "provocative and enlightening" account of "the myths and contradictions upon which our political and legal institutions rest," one that may "facilitate transforming those institutions into more emancipatory forms."<ref>Sossin 523-524</ref> Sossin notes that Unger would add "prophecy" and "vision" to the pursuits of critical theory.<ref>Sossin 524</ref> Sossin concludes that "''What Should Legal Analysis Become?'' is in many ways an illustration of Unger practicing what he preaches—reinventing and recombining ideas and elements of his previous thought into a reinvigorated critique. His analysis never fails to engage, though ... it does leave important questions unanswered."<ref>Sossin 534</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources==
Kar, Robin Bradley. "Legal Analysis and the Perversions of Theory (review of ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?''), 106 Yale Law Journal 2685 (1997)
Sossin, Lorne. "The Politics of Imagination" (review of ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?'') 47 University of Toronto Law Journal 523 (1997)
Unger, Roberto Mangabeira. ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?''. Verso Books, 1996.
Waldron, Jeremy. "Dirty Little Secret" (review of ''What Should Legal Analysis Become?''), 98 Columbia Law Review 510 (1998).

The '''worm-like chain''' ('''WLC''') model in [[polymer physics]] is used to describe the behavior of [[polymers]] that are semi-flexible: fairly stiff with successive segments pointing in roughly the same direction, and with [[persistence length]] within a few orders of magnitude of the polymer length. The WLC model is the continuous version of the [[Otto Kratky|Kratky]]-[[Günther Porod|Porod]] model.
== Model elements == [[File:Worm-like Chain.png|thumb|An illustration of the WLC model, with position and unit tangent vectors as shown.|250x250px]] The WLC model envisions a continuously flexible [[isotropic]] rod.<ref name=Doi>{{cite book | author=Doi and Edwards | title=The Theory of Polymer Dynamics | year=1988}}</ref><ref name=Rubinstein>{{cite book | author=Rubinstein and Colby | title=Polymer Physics | year=2003}}</ref><ref name=Kirby>{{cite book | author=Kirby, B.J. | title=Micro- and Nanoscale Fluid Mechanics: Transport in Microfluidic Devices | url=http://www.kirbyresearch.com/textbook}}</ref> This is in contrast to the [[Ideal chain|freely-jointed chain]] model, which is only flexible between discrete freely hinged segments. The model is particularly suited for describing stiffer polymers, with successive segments displaying a sort of cooperativity: nearby segments are roughly aligned. At room temperature, the polymer adopts a smoothly curved conformation; at <math>T = 0</math> K, the polymer adopts a rigid rod conformation.<ref name=Doi/>
For a polymer of maximum length <math>L_0</math>, parametrize the path of the polymer as <math>s \in(0,L_0)</math>. Allow <math>\hat t(s)</math> to be the unit tangent vector to the chain at point <math>s</math>, and <math>\vec r(s)</math> to be the position vector along the chain, as shown to the right. Then:
:<math>\hat t(s) \equiv \frac {\partial \vec r(s) }{\partial s}</math> and the end-to-end distance <math>\vec R = \int_{0}^{L_0}\hat t(s) ds</math> .<ref name=Doi/>
The energy associated with the bending of the polymer can be written as:
<math> E = \frac {1}{2}k_B T \int_{0}^{L_0} P \cdot \left (\frac {\partial^2 \vec r(s) }{\partial s^2}\right )^{2} ds</math>
where <math>P</math> is the polymer's characteristic [[persistence length]], <math>k_B</math> is the [[Boltzmann constant]], and <math>T</math> is the absolute temperature. At finite temperatures, the end-to end distance of the polymer will be significantly shorter than the maximum length <math>L_0</math>. This is caused by thermal fluctuations, which result in a coiled, random configuration of the undisturbed polymer.
The polymer's orientation [[correlation function]] can then be solved for, and it follows an [[exponential decay]] with decay constant 1/P:<ref name="Doi" /><ref name="Kirby" />
<math>\langle\hat t(s) \cdot \hat t(0)\rangle=\langle \cos \; \theta (s)\rangle = e^{-s/P}\,</math>
[[File:Crossover from flexible to stiff behavior in the worm-like chain polymer model.svg|thumb|300x300px|Mean squared end-to-end distance as a function of persistence length.]]
A useful value is the mean square end-to-end distance of the polymer:<ref name="Doi" /><ref name="Kirby" />
<math> \langle R^{2} \rangle = \langle \vec R \cdot \vec R \rangle = \left\langle \int_{0}^{L_0} \hat t(s) ds \cdot \int_{0}^{L_0} \hat t(s') ds' \right\rangle = \int_{0}^{L_0} ds \int_{0}^{L_0} \langle \hat t(s) \cdot \hat t(s') \rangle ds'= \int_{0}^{L_0} ds \int_{0}^{L_0} e^{-\left | s - s' \right | / P} ds' </math>
<math> \langle R^{2} \rangle = 2 PL_0 \left [ 1 - \frac {P}{L_0} \left ( 1 - e^{-L_0/P} \right ) \right ] </math>
Note that in the limit of <math>L_0 \gg P</math>, then <math>\langle R^{2} \rangle = 2PL_0</math>. This can be used to show that a [[Kuhn length|Kuhn segment]] is equal to twice the [[persistence length]] of a worm-like chain. In the limit of <math>L_0 \ll P</math>, then <math>\langle R^{2} \rangle = L_0^2</math>, and the polymer displays rigid rod behavior.<ref name="Rubinstein" /> The figure to the right shows the crossover from flexible to stiff behavior as the [[persistence length]] increases.
[[File:Worm-like Chain Model vs. DNA.svg|thumb|325px|Comparison between the worm-like chain model and experimental data from the stretching of λ-DNA.<ref name=":0" />]]
== Biological relevance == Experimental data from the stretching of [[Lambda phage]] DNA is shown to the right, with force measurements determined by analysis of [[Brownian Motion|Brownian]] fluctuations of a [[Magnetic bead|bead]] attached to the DNA. A [[persistence length]] of 51.35 nm and a contour length of 1318 nm were used for the model, which is depicted by the solid line.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Bouchiat|first1=C|title=Estimating the Persistence Length of a Worm-Like Chain Molecule from Force-Extension Measurements|journal=Biophysical Journal|date=1999|doi=10.1016/S0006-3495(99)77207-3|url=https://www.cell.com/biophysj/fulltext/S0006-3495(99)77207-3|bibcode=1999BpJ....76..409B}}</ref>
Other biologically important polymers that can be effectively modeled as worm-like chains include:
* double-stranded [[DNA]] (persistence length 40-50 nm) and [[RNA]] (persistence length 64 nm)<ref name="Kirby" /><ref name="dekker2005">{{cite journal | author=J. A. Abels and F. Moreno-Herrero and T. van der Heijden and C. Dekker and N. H. Dekker | title=Single-Molecule Measurements of the Persistence Length of Double-Stranded RNA | journal=Biophysical Journal| year=2005| volume=88| pages=2737–2744| doi=10.1529/biophysj.104.052811 | bibcode=2005BpJ....88.2737A}}</ref> * single-stranded DNA (persistence length 4 nm) <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bernard|first1=Tinland|title=Persistence Length of Single-Stranded DNA|journal=Macromolecules|date=1997|doi=10.1021/ma970381+|url=https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ma970381+}}</ref> * unstructured RNA (persistence length 2 nm) <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chen|first1=Huimin|last2=Meisburger|first2=Steve P.|title=Ionic strength-dependent persistence lengths of single-stranded RNA and DNA|journal=PNAS|date=2011|doi=10.1073/pnas.1119057109|pmc=3271905|bibcode=2012PNAS..109..799C}}</ref> * unstructured [[proteins]] (persistence length 0.6-0.7 nm)<ref name="lapidus2002">{{cite journal | author=L. J. Lapidus and P. J. Steinbach and W. A. Eaton and A. Szabo and J. Hofrichter | title=Single-Molecule Effects of Chain Stiffness on the Dynamics of Loop Formation in Polypeptides. Appendix: Testing a 1-Dimensional Diffusion Model for Peptide Dynamics | journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry B| year=2002| volume=106| pages=11628–11640| doi=10.1021/jp020829v}}</ref> * [[microtubules]] (persistence length 0.52 cm) <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gittes|first1=F|title=Flexural rigidity of microtubules and actin filaments measured from thermal fluctuations in shape|journal=Journal of Cell Biology|date=1993|doi=10.1083/jcb.120.4.923|url=http://jcb.rupress.org/content/120/4/923}}</ref>
== Stretching worm-like chain polymers == Upon stretching, the accessible spectrum of thermal fluctuations reduces, which causes an entropic force acting against the external elongation. This entropic force can be estimated from considering the total energy of the polymer:
<math> H = H_{\rm elastic} + H_{\rm external}= \frac {1}{2}k_B T \int_{0}^{L_0} P \cdot \left (\frac {\partial^2 \vec r(s) }{\partial s^2}\right )^{2} ds - xF</math>.
Here, the [[contour length]] is represented by <math>L_0</math>, the [[persistence length]] by <math>P</math>, the extension is represented by <math>x</math>, and external force is represented by <math>F</math>.
Laboratory tools such as [[atomic force microscopy]] (AFM) and [[optical tweezers]] have been used to characterize the force-dependent stretching behavior of biological polymers. An interpolation formula that approximates the force-extension behavior with about 15% relative error is:<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Marko|first1=J.F.|last2=Siggia|first2=E.D.|title=Statistical mechanics of supercoiled DNA|journal=Phys. Rev. E|date=1995|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.52.2912|bibcode=1995PhRvE..52.2912M}}</ref>
:<math>\frac {FP} {k_{B}T} = \frac {1}{4} \left ( 1 - \frac {x} {L_0} \right )^{-2} - \frac {1}{4} + \frac {x}{L_0}</math>
A more accurate approximation for the force-extension behavior with about 1% relative error is:<ref name=Petrosyan>{{cite journal|last=Petrosyan|first=R.|title=Improved approximations for some polymer extension models|journal=Rehol Acta|year=2016|doi = 10.1007/s00397-016-0977-9|arxiv=1606.02519 }}</ref>
:<math>\frac {FP} {k_{B}T} = \frac {1}{4} \left ( 1 - \frac {x} {L_0} \right )^{-2} - \frac {1}{4} + \frac {x}{L_0}-0.8 \left (\frac {x} {L_0} \right )^{2.15}</math> :
A corresponding approximation for the extension-force behavior, also with about 1% relative error, was reported:<ref name=Petrosyan/>
:<math>\frac {x} {L_0} = \frac {4}{3} - \frac {4} {3\sqrt{\frac {FP} {k_{B}T} + 1}} -\frac {10e^{\sqrt[4]{900\frac {k_{B}T} {FP}}}} {\sqrt{\frac {FP} {k_{B}T}} \left(e^{\sqrt[4]{900\frac {k_{B}T} {FP}}}-1 \right)^{2} } + \frac {\left (\frac {FP} {k_{B}T}\right)^{1.62}} {3.55+3.8\left ( \frac {FP} {k_{B}T}\right)^{2.2}}</math>
== Extensible worm-like chain model ==
The elastic response from extension cannot be neglected: polymers elongate due to external forces. This enthalpic compliance is accounted for the material parameter <math>K_0</math>, and the system yields the following Hamiltonian for significantly extended polymers:
<math> H = H_{\rm elastic}+H_{\rm enthalpic}+H_{\rm external} = \frac {1}{2}k_B T \int_{0}^{L_0} P \cdot \left (\frac {\partial \vec r(s) }{\partial s}\right )^{2} ds + \frac {1}{2}\frac {K_0}{L_0} x^{2} - xF </math>,
This expression contains both the entropic term, which describes changes in the polymer conformation, and the enthalpic term, which describes the stretching of the polymer due to the external force. Several approximations for the force-extension behavior have been put forward, depending on the applied external force. These approximations are made for stretching DNA in physiological conditions (near neutral pH, ionic strength approximately 100 mM, room temperature), with stretch modulus around 1000 pN.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wang|first=Michelle D.|author2=Hong Yin|author3=Robert Landick|author4=Jeff Gelles|author5=Steven M. Block|year=1997|title=Stretching DNA with Optical Tweezers|journal=Biophysical Journal|volume=72|pages=1335–1346|bibcode=1997BpJ....72.1335W|doi=10.1016/S0006-3495(97)78780-0|pmc=1184516|pmid=9138579}}</ref><ref>Murugesapillai D ''et al'', [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12551-016-0236-4 Single-molecule studies of high-mobility group B architectural DNA bending proteins], Biophys Rev (2016) doi:10.1007/s12551-016-0236-4</ref>
For the low-force regime (F < about 10 pN), the following interpolation formula was derived:<ref>{{cite journal|last=Marko|first=J.F.|author2=Eric D. Siggia |title=Stretching DNA|journal=Macromolecules|year=1995|volume=28|pages=8759–8770|bibcode = 1995MaMol..28.8759M |doi = 10.1021/ma00130a008 }}</ref>
<math>\frac {FP} {k_{B}T} = \frac {1}{4} \left ( 1 - \frac {x} {L_0} + \frac {F}{K_0} \right )^{-2} - \frac {1}{4} + \frac {x}{L_0} - \frac {F}{K_0}</math>.
For the higher-force regime, where the polymer is significantly extended, the following approximation is valid:<ref>{{cite journal|last=Odijk|first=Theo|title=Stiff Chains and Filaments under Tension|journal=Macromolecules|year=1995|volume=28|pages=7016–7018|bibcode = 1995MaMol..28.7016O |doi = 10.1021/ma00124a044 }}</ref>
<math>x = L_0 \left ( 1 - \frac {1} {2} \left ( \frac {k_{B}T}{FP} \right )^{1/2} + \frac {F}{K_0}\right ) </math>.
More accurate interpolation formulas for the force-extension and extension-force behaviors are:<ref name=Petrosyan/>
:<math>\frac {FP} {k_{B}T} = \frac {1}{4} \left ( 1 - \frac {x} {L_0}+ \frac {F}{K_0} \right )^{-2} - \frac {1}{4} + \frac {x}{L_0} - \frac {F}{K_0}-0.8 \left (\frac {x} {L_0}- \frac {F}{K_0} \right )^{2.15}</math>
:<math>\frac {x} {L_0} = \frac {4}{3} - \frac {4} {3\sqrt{\frac {FP} {k_{B}T} + 1}} -\frac {10e^{\sqrt[4]{900\frac {k_{B}T} {FP}}}} {\sqrt{\frac {FP} {k_{B}T}} \left(e^{\sqrt[4]{900\frac {k_{B}T} {FP}}}-1 \right)^{2} } + \frac {\left (\frac {FP} {k_{B}T}\right)^{1.62}} {3.55+3.8\left ( \frac {FP} {k_{B}T}\right)^{2.2}} + \frac {F}{K_0}</math>
